text.p: Here are highlights from Polish newspapers this morning.
FRONT PAGE POLITICAL NEWS
- Turkey will support Poland on its way to NATO, Turkey's President Suleyman Demirel told Poland's President Aleksander Kwasniewski in Warsaw.
ECONOMIC AND MARKET STORIES
RZECZPOSPOLITA
- The state treasury has proposed that the Gdansk shipyard should reach a bankruptcy agreement with its creditors to facilitate the purchase of a strategic stake in the yard by the Szczecin shipyard.

- A consortium led by France's Hachette Distribution Services is suing Poland's State Treasury in the Warsaw provincial court for 1.165 million shares priced at 10 zlotys per share in state-owned newstand chain Ruch SA.

- The Polskie Towarzystwo Reasekuracyjne (PTR) reinsurance firm plans to increase share capital by up to 120 million zlotys through an ex-rights share issue, its president Krzysztof Jarmuszczak said. The firm's share capital is now 65 million zlotys.

- The French-Polish Bank Inicjatyw Spoleczno Ekonomicznych (BISE) will increase share capital by up to 10 million zlotys. France's CIAL bank has already offered to buy all of the new share issue and other stakeholders are in talks with BISE.
DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI

- Europe's A-4 motorway stretch of 126 kilometres between Wroclaw and Gliwice will be built by 2000. The construction will cost 350 million European Currency Units (ECU) and will be financed from the public budget and foreign credits.
- Dunlop, controlled by Japan's Sumitomo group, has an 8.0 percent share in Poland's tire market and plans to push it up by 2.0 percent by 2000, Dunlop's marketing agent SP Opony said.
- The withdrawal of Rothmans of Pall Mall cigarette concern from the Lubelskie Zaklady Tytoniowe plant in Lublin, eastern Poland, resulted in a lay off of 300 workers, the company said.
- The listed Okocim brewery is considering the construction of a trading and services centre in Krakow, southern Poland, Krakow municipality said.

- The TU Inter Fortuna Zycie (Life) insurance firm has received an operating licence from the PUNU state insurance supervision office. Germany's Inter group holds a 64 percent stake in the new firm and the rest is controlled by Fortuna non-life insurance .
- The Drukpress printing plant, controlled by Germany's Passauer Neue Presse, has taken over the Echo Krakowa daily in return for the newspaper's debts.
- Austria's Billa supermarket chain has opened a new big supermarket in Sopot, north Poland, covering 5,000 metres, Billa said.
- The Szczecin shipyard launched the tanker Helix on Wednesday, the biggest vessel ever built in the yard.
GAZETA WYBORCZA

- Poland's finance ministry has bought part of the Brady bonds held by banks belonging to the London Club, cutting the country's foreign debt by 4.0 percent. The purchase was financed through a loan drawn from the National Bank of Poland (NBP), the central bank.
- Poland's state treasury will buy back the Calisia piano maker in Kalisz, central Poland, from the Fibigier family who reclaimed the plant after 1989, the family's proxy Elvira Fibigier said.
PARKIET

- The Polish Securities Commission (KPW) gave a public trading permit to 65 million shares of Bank Handlowy in Warsaw priced at 4.0 zlotys per share. KPW also allowed the sale of Handlowy's global depository receipts by the Bank of New York.
